page.title: 02OUTSTANDING FEATURES
page.content: Running from Anglezarke Moor in the west to Darwen and Turton Moors in the east, the height varies from 267 metres at the Belmont Reservoir's edge to 396 metres at Cartridge Hill, with Great Hill and Old Adam's Hill being also easily distinguishable. There is a cairn on Old Adam's Hill, and Hanging Stones on Turton Moor are reputed to have been used to execute sheep stealers in years gone by. Spitler's Edge is a well-used walk way and is the ancient boundary between Sharples and Anglezarke townships. The A675, which bisects the block north to south, follows the line of the Bolton to Nightingales Turnpike (except where it has been diverted around the reservoir). A toll house, Longworth Bar, once stood in the layby in Block 7.
